Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility on grounds of serious criminality
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of immigration officer's decision to deny H&C application
Crimes.Application_Facts: Lalane convicted of multiple crimes; argued deportation to Haiti would cause hardship due to health (pacemaker), family ties, and country conditions
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Exemption from applying for permanent residence outside Canada on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged unusual or disproportionate hardship upon deportation
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Unusual or disproportionate hardship under IRPA s. 25
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Criminal record, lack of personalized risk, general country conditions in Haiti, health, family ties
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Lalane failed to provide sufficient evidence of personalized hardship
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Medical reports, country condition reports, criminal record, family relationship documentation
Crimes.Evidence_Assessed: Generalized country conditions not equivalent to personalized risk
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent resident status in Canada despite inadmissibility
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Minister may exempt foreign nationals from visa requirements if refusal causes unusual or disproportionate hardship
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of concrete evidence showing unique hardship beyond general conditions in Haiti
Crimes.Harm_Assessment: No unusual or disproportionate hardship established
Crimes.Cause_Description: Denial of H&C application due to criminal inadmissibility
Crimes.Evidence_Handling: Officer considered all submitted evidence but found it insufficient
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: None directly; issue was eligibility under IRPA
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Lalane resided in Canada as a permanent resident but became inadmissible
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority of immigration officer under federal immigration law
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Balanced all factors including criminality and family ties
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Hardship not disproportionate compared to others in similar situation; re-establishment in Haiti possible

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Criminal inadmissibility based on violent offense
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Part of pattern of criminal behavior
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Health issues, family ties in Canada
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient to establish conviction and sentencing
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Presumed credible as official legal documents
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not challenged; focus on immigration consequences
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Risk to public safety due to history of violence
Crimes.Jurisdiction: Federal immigration authorities over criminal inadmissibility
Crimes.Standard_of_Proof: Balance of probabilities in immigration context

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration consequence of breaching court order
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether breach contributed to serious criminality finding
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Considered as part of overall criminal conduct
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show unusual hardship
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: History of non-compliance with legal orders
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Exemption allowed only under exceptional circumstances
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Fair consideration of all H&C factors
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of hardship upon return to Haiti
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Officer reviewed submissions and provided reasoning
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Criminal record, medical condition, family connections
Crimes.Applicant_Challenge: Decision lacked compassion or ignored key facts
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Argued health and family justified exemption
Crimes.Authority: Minister of Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Serious criminality due to multiple offenses including breach of probation
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Minister may grant exemption based on H&C grounds

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Inadmissibility due to involvement in drug trafficking conspiracy
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: Controlled Drugs and Substances Act, IRPA
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Whether all evidence was properly considered
Crimes.Evidence_Disclosure_Status: All relevant evidence disclosed and assessed
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Nature and seriousness of the offense, potential danger to society
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Link between criminal activity and threat to public order
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Unusual or disproportionate hardship under IRPA s. 25
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Seriousness of crime outweighed H&C considerations
Crimes.Charter_Issues: Section 7 (life, liberty, security) invoked but not violated
Crimes.Basis_for_Inadmissibility: Conviction for an indictable offense punishable by at least 10 years
Crimes.Accusation: Planning and participating in international drug importation
Crimes.Risk_Persecution: Not applicable – risk is reintegration, not persecution
Crimes.Mode_of_Entry: Lawful permanent resident status previously granted
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Eligibility for H&C relief after serious crime
Crimes.Relevant_Factors_Considered: Criminal record, health, family, country conditions

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Inadmissibility due to conviction for importing controlled substances
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: Controlled Drugs and Substances Act, IRPA
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Whether decision maker fairly evaluated H&C arguments
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Connection to transnational crime and public safety
Crimes.Charter_Issues: Section 7 rights raised but not infringed
Crimes.Basis_for_Inadmissibility: Indictable offense with maximum penalty over 10 years
Crimes.Risk_Assessment_Factors: Scale of operation, intent to distribute
Crimes.Accusation: Physically bringing illegal drugs into Canada
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Adequacy of reasons provided by officer
Crimes.Risk_Persecution: No claim of persecution; concern about reintegration
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Availability of H&C relief despite serious crime
Crimes.Relevant_Factors_Considered: Criminal history, health, family, Haiti conditions

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether possession offense constitutes serious criminality
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Pattern of criminal behavior reduces sympathy
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Health and family ties justify stay
Crimes.Applicant_Challenge: Decision too rigid, ignored human element
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Seeks compassion due to health and roots in Canada
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Serious criminality due to cumulative offenses
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Minister may exempt if refusal causes unusual hardship

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of narcotics for the purpose of trafficking
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Eligibility for H&C relief after trafficking-level offense
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to prove exceptional circumstances
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Criminal history undermines credibility of hardship claims
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Health risks, family separation, poor conditions in Haiti
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Pacemaker condition, family in Canada, Haiti country report
Crimes.Applicant_Challenge: Decision failed to account for true hardship
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Argued rehabilitation and integration in Canada
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Medical records, character references, criminal history
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Stay in Canada as permanent resident
Crimes.Authority: Minister of Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Serious criminality based on drug trafficking offense
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Minister may waive requirements on H&C grounds
